What is binge eating disorder (BED)?

Binge eating disorder, now a distinct diagnosis in DSM-5®, is characterized by1:

  • Recurring episodes (at least once weekly for 3 months) of consuming a large amount of food in a short period of time, compared with others
  • A feeling of a lack of control over eating during an episode
  • Marked distress regarding binge eating

During a binge, adults with BED may eat much more rapidly than normal, eat until they are uncomfortably full, eat large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry, and/or eat alone out of embarrassment. They may feel disgusted with themselves, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

Diagnosis should be based on a complete evaluation of the patient. These are not the complete diagnostic criteria, but instead a brief summary.

Register for additional information on BED including the full DSM-5® diagnostic criteria
binge eating disorder
in adults

This site is intended for US health care professionals only.

Binge eating disorder (BED)
is a cycle of…

Binge. Distress. Repeat.1

Identifying and accurately diagnosing adults with BED is the first step to helping them.

What is BED?

BED, now a distinct disorder in DSM-5®, is defined as recurring episodes (≥ once weekly, for at least 3 months) of consuming a large amount of food in a short time, compared with others. Patients feel a lack of control during a binge and marked distress over their eating. They typically experience shame and guilt, among other symptoms, about their bingeing, and may conceal these symptoms, even from you.1

BED affects nearly
3 million US adults2,3

Estimated 12-month prevalence in National Comorbidity Survey Replication of US adults aged ≥18 years, extrapolated to full US population aged ≥18 years.2,3
BED is the most common eating disorder among US adults and more than twice as prevalent as bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa combined2

The gender ratio is far less skewed in BED than in bulimia nervosa.1,2

12-month prevalence in US adults2:

BED: 2 to 1
1.6% of women vs 0.8% of men

Bulimia nervosa: 5 to 1
0.5% of women vs 0.1% of men

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults aged ≥18 years.

Prevalence rates are comparable among non-Latino white (1.4%), Latino (2.1%), Asian (1.2%), and African American (1.5%) adults in the US4

Sample from a combined data set of 3 nationally representative US samples.4

BED occurs with roughly similar frequencies in most industrialized countries (eg, Australia, Canada,
many European countries, New Zealand, and the United States).1

In an online survey, only 3% of US adults who met DSM-5® criteria for BED reported being diagnosed with BED by a health care provider in the past 12 months.5
 
Data from a 2013 online survey of adults aged ≥18 years. Of 22,397 respondents, 344 met DSM-5® criteria for BED in the previous 12 months.5

Essential features
of binge eating disorder

In order to be diagnosed with BED, an individual must meet all
of the following DSM-5® diagnostic criteria.1

  1. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of
    binge eating is characterized by both of the following:
    1. Eating, in a discrete period of time (eg, within any
      2-hour period), an amount of food that is definitely
      larger than what most people would eat in a similar
      period of time under similar circumstances.
    2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the
      episode (eg, a feeling that one cannot stop eating or
      control what or how much one is eating).
  2. The binge eating episodes are associated with 3
    (or more)     of the following:
    1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.
    2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.
    3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.
    4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.
    5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.
  3. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.
  4. Episodes occur, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.
  5. Not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior
    as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during the course of bulimia nervosa
    or anorexia nervosa.

Diagnosis should be based upon a
complete evaluation of the patient.

Register to receive the full DSM-5® diagnostic criteria and additional BED information from Shire

What are common
triggers of binge eating?

As noted in DSM-5®, negative affect most commonly precedes a bingeing episode.1

Other triggers include1:

  • Interpersonal stressors
  • Dietary restraint
  • Negative feelings related to body weight, body shape, and food
  • Boredom
What are common triggers of binge eating?

BED onset occurs later than other eating disorders

In a survey of US adults, the median age of onset (21 years) was several years later
than for anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa (18 years).*2

Age-of-onset ranges for BED, AN, and BN2

Age-of-onset ranges
for BED, AN, and BN2

Interquartile range.
AN=anorexia nervosa;
BN=bulimia nervosa.

The mean duration of BED is 8.1 years.2

BED is associated with significant psychiatric comorbidity comparable to bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa1

Adults with BED often have coexisting bipolar, depressive, or anxiety disorders.1

Lifetime comorbidity per DSM-IV® in a nationally representative
survey of US adults aged ≥18 years*2:

79%

met criteria for
at least 1 other
psychiatric disorder

49%

met criteria for
3 or more other
psychiatric disorders

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a nationally representative face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults
aged ≥18 years.2

BED in adults is associated with a range of functional consequences1

Functional consequences may include1:

  • Social role adjustment problems
  • Impaired health-related quality
    of life
  • Decreased life satisfaction
  • Increased medical morbidity and mortality
  • Increased health care utilization compared with body mass index (BMI)–matched control subjects
  • Increased risk for weight gain and development of obesity

In a nationally representative survey of US adults aged ≥18 years2:

63%

reported functional
impairment during
the past year (Sheehan
Disability Scale)

19%

reported
severe impairment

Data from an eating disorder–assessed subsample (n=2,980) of the National Comorbidity Survey Replication, a face-to-face household survey of English-speaking adults aged ≥18 years.2

While the exact cause is unknown,

Research suggests BED may have a neurobiological basis and genetic and environmental influences6-12

Reward center and impulsivity dysregulation

Adults with BED have shown reduced activity
in impulse control–related regions of the brain6

Neurotransmitter dysregulation

Dopamine signaling converts sensory stimuli
into processes that may generate or enhance wanting
of a particular food7-9

Endogenous μ-opioid signaling dysfunction

Opioid signaling converts sensory stimuli
into processes that generate or enhance “liking” of a particular food8,9

Research also suggests that risk factors for BED may include:

  • Genetic influences7,10
    • BED appears to run in families, which may reflect additive genetic influences
    • Genetic differences in neurobiological components
      of the brain’s reward center have been observed
  • Environmental influences
    • In a case-controlled retrospective assessment of 162 women with BED,
      stressful life events were reported more frequently in the year preceding BED onset than in non-BED controls11
    • In a nationally representative survey of 5,702 adults, of the men (n=30) and women (n=75) who reported BED, 98% and 90%, respectively, reported experiencing some form of trauma*12

*Types of trauma included combat experience, life-threatening accident, and physical
or sexual assault.12

Recognizing BED

BED is defined as recurring episodes of eating a large amount of food in a short period of time, with episodes characterized by feelings of lack of control and marked distress.1

These are not the full diagnostic criteria. Please register to receive the full DSM-5® diagnostic criteria and additional BED information from Shire.

BED is different from bulimia nervosa

It is not associated with compensatory behaviors such as purging or excessive exercise, or with dietary restriction, although frequent dieting may be reported.1

BED is different from overeating

While overeating is a challenge for many Americans, recurrent binge eating is much less common, far more severe, and is associated with significant physical and psychological problems.13

BED is different from obesity

As noted in DSM-5®, compared with weight-matched obese adults without BED, obese adults with BED consume more calories in laboratory studies of eating behavior and have1:

  • Greater functional impairment
  • Lower quality of life
  • More subjective distress
  • Greater psychiatric comorbidity

BED occurs in normal-weight, overweight, and obese individuals2

Based on a nationally representative survey of US adults aged ≥18 years2:

<50%

of adults with BED
are obese

19%

are normal weight
(BMI 18.5-24.9)

36%

are overweight
(BMI 25-29.9)

but not obese
(BMI ≥30)

Resources

Now that you have a better understanding of BED, you know what to
look for in your practice.

Starting the conversation

These questions may help you begin a dialogue with your adult patients about
their eating behavior and feelings toward food.

General screening14

  • Do you worry that you have lost control over how much you eat?
  • Would you say that food dominates your life?

Specific for BED diagnosis15

  • Do you often eat within any 2-hour period what
    most people would regard as an unusual amount of food?
  • During these binges, did you eat…
    • Much more rapidly than normal?
    • Until you felt uncomfortably full?
    • Large amounts of food when you didn’t feel
      physically hungry?
    • Alone because you were embarrassed by how
      much you were eating?
  • Was it very upsetting to you that you couldn’t stop
    eating or control what or how much you were eating?
  • How often did you binge?
